etymology.description: ideogrammic: originally depicting two people standing side-by-side.
etymology.interpretation: Two figures placed together convey the sense of being side by side, extending to ideas of togetherness and combination. Over time it broadened into the conjunction “and” and the verb meaning “to merge.”
etymology.simplification: Mainland simplification adopted the long-used clerical/variant form 并, reducing strokes and unifying variants (並/竝/幷) into one form.

examples.chinese: 她聪明并且勤奋(她聰明並且勤奮)。
我们并不同意你的看法(我們並不同意你的看法)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen bìng bù tóngyì nǐ de kànfǎ.
examples.english: We do not agree with your view at all.

examples.chinese: 两家公司并成一家(兩家公司併成一家)。
examples.pinyin: Liǎng jiā gōngsī bìng chéng yī jiā.
examples.english: The two companies merged into one.
